did.abstract: The Gay Men's Health Crisis (GMHC), America's oldest AIDS organization, formed in 1982, serves to educate the public about HIV/AIDS, provide care services for People with AIDS (PWAs), and advocate at all levels of government for fair AIDS policies. It is a volunteer-supported, community-based organization that provides programs to clients and members of the general public regardless of HIV status, gender, or sexual orientation. The records document the three aspects of GMHC's activities and contain correspondence, memoranda, minutes, pamphlets, photographs, posters, questionnaires, reports, surveys, video recordings, and other material. The bulk of the collection consists of correspondence, memoranda, and reports regarding GMHC's safe sex education programs and client services.

bioghist.p: Introduction

The Gay Men's Health Crisis (GMHC), America's oldest AIDS organization, organized in 1982, serves to educate the public about HIV/AIDS, provide care services for People with AIDS (PWAs), and advocate at all levels of government for fair AIDS policies. It is a volunteer-supported, community-based organization that provides programs to clients and members of the general public regardless of HIV status, gender, or sexual orientation.

GMHC was founded by six gay men, Nathan Fain, Larry Kramer, Lawrence Mass, Paul Popham, Paul Rapoport, and Edmund White, at Kramer's Manhattan apartment on January 4, 1982. They had all been part of an earlier gathering at Kramer's on August 11, 1981, where Dr. Alvin Friedman-Kien discussed the "gay cancer" that was affecting their friends and lovers. Over $6,600 was raised at that meeting for research into Kaposi's sarcoma at New York University's Medical Center. When the six met in January 1982, they discussed raising more funds for research and organized GMHC's first major event at the Paradise Garage on April 8. The event was called Showers and $50,000 was raised.

While Showers was a success, the group realized that they could do more than simply raise money to help those affected. They decided to try to answer the many questions people had about the disease. The first service provided by the organization was the Hotline, which began in May as an answering machine in the apartment of volunteer, Rodger McFarlane, who later became the organization's second executive director. On the first night, 100 calls were received. While many of the questions could be answered over the phone, some of them required the help of medical, legal, and other professionals to answer. As there was no social service agency to which GMHC could direct these callers, they created the Patient Services Division to provide further help.
Service

In September, Dr. Ken Wein joined as the first Clinical Director and organized the Crisis Intervention Counselors. The Counselors assisted men who had recently fallen ill and who called the Hotline, were otherwise referred to GMHC, needed assistance maneuvering through the health care system, required help at home, or sought other support that could not be provided over the phone. At this time, McFarlane and others had been spending their spare time caring for friends and lovers who were neither able to take care of themselves at home nor represent their own best interests within the health care system. The situation in hospitals was especially critical as these men had to take on the duties of hospital workers, who refused to touch patients or enter their rooms to deliver food.

GMHC created the Buddy Program that September to consolidate the work of these men and to develop a program to train volunteers in assisting PWAs. The program began with 20 men who were on call 24 hours a day to provide assistance, but quickly grew as more men were affected by the disease. The program was staffed entirely of volunteers and initially consisted of people helping friends and lovers affected by AIDS with basic tasks such as grocery shopping, laundry, pet care, as well as spending time with the PWAs. As alarm spread about the disease and hospital staff refused to care for PWAs, Buddies also began to provide nursing care for PWAs and act as intermediaries with social and medical services. A new volunteer position was created to handle the latter and was called Crisis Intervention Worker (CIW). A handful of registered nurses volunteered at GMHC to train people in basic care (bathing, changing, feeding, etc.) of patients.
In 1985, the volunteer position of Crisis Management Partner (CMP) was created and combined the duties of a Buddy and a CIW. CMPs were assigned to PWAs with a number of emotional and physical needs.

As the AIDS epidemic grew and more people became infected, Client Services expanded to provide additional services for PWAs who were able to leave their homes through Recreation Services and Group Support Services programs. Recreation Services consisted of workshops in art, photography, writing, and bridge, trips to museums and other cultural institutions, movies, lunches, and parties. Group Support Services provided group counseling for PWAs and their care partners. These services provided a safe and informal setting to cope with the emotional and social problems associated with AIDS and fostered support networks. By 1985, there were ten groups specifically for PWAs, eleven for their care partners, as well as weekly walk-in groups for PWAs, care partners, family; groups for children with AIDS and their families; and groups for couples dealing with the disease.

Financial Advocacy Services, Legal Services, and the Office of the Ombudsman quickly followed. These services provided free advice to PWAs, kept them abreast of changes in federal services available to them, and provided advocacy for clients with problems with the healthcare system.

As PWAs began living longer and new treatments became available, Client Services began providing Nutrition Counseling, expanded its Recreation Services to include hot meals five days a week as well as other events, and created new Support Groups to meet the needs of communities within the larger AIDS community including women; Latinos and other people of color; and people with chemical dependencies.

By 1987, GMHC had created a position for a Deputy Executive Director for Program Operations which, following a restructuring of the organization in 1989, assumed responsibility for the administration of all of the Client Services programs: Client Advocacy, Education Department, Nutrition and Recreation Services, Legal Services, the Ombudsman Department, and the Volunteer Office.

In 1990, the enactment of the Ryan White CARE Act allowed GMHC to expand existing programs and create new ones. Within the next few years, GMHC created a number of programs which included a permanent Deaf AIDS Project (DAP), the Lesbian AIDS Project, and the Tuberculosis Education and Treatment Support Program. By 1993, Education once again became its own department, with its head reporting directly to the Executive Director.
Education

With the discovery of HIV in 1983, GMHC began its mission of education in earnest. Safe sex brochures and guidelines were published and distributed to bathhouses and gay bars. GMHC began staffing information tables around New York City with literature about AIDS and volunteers who could answer questions about AIDS and GMHC's services. Publication of the Health Letter began, providing statistics and research updates. GMHC was recognized as a leader in providing accurate and up-to-date information on AIDS and was consulted by the media, doctors, and health organizations.

In 1984 the Centers for Disease Control asked GMHC to assist them in creating public conferences on AIDS and in April 1985 they were part of the organizing committee of the first International AIDS Conference in Atlanta.

GMHC's AIDS Prevention program was developed in March 1985 once condoms were proven to be an effective means of preventing HIV transmission. It created programs to disseminate safe sex methods to the gay community and the growing number of other groups affected by the disease.

By October 1986, GMHC's client base had expanded to include heterosexual men and women, hemophiliacs, intravenous drug-users, and children. This led to innovations in AIDS education by GMHC, including the Medical Information Department which published Treatment Issues and provided information on new therapies; showed that safe sex could be fun through sexually explicit material, such as the Safer Sex Comix; and created outreach programs designed to adapt the original sex education classes to African-Americans, Latinos, and lesbians.

The Education Department began an audiovisual program in the mid-1980s which developed the weekly show Living with AIDS; produced public service announcements and safe sex videos which were shown at safe sex forums, sex clubs, and porn theatres; and created an oral history project in which some founders of GMHC were interviewed as well as a number of staff members in the late 1980s.

In the 1990s the department produced safe sex guidelines for lesbians; created programs for HIV-negative gay and bisexual men; expanded programs aimed at African-American and Latino men; and improved education for teens.
Advocacy

GMHC's advocacy work began in October 1983 with the funding of litigation brought by the Lambda Legal Defense Fund in the first AIDS discrimination case. A New York physician, Dr. Joseph Sonnabend, was threatened with eviction from his office because he was treating PWAs and the building's board felt that this would decrease property values. The case was decided in Sonnabend's favor.

Timothy J. Sweeney joined the staff of GMHC in 1986 as the Deputy Executive Director of Policy and created the Public Policy Department. The Department began to fight for increased funding for AIDS research, health care for PWAs, prevention programs, and greater civil rights protections for everyone affected by AIDS. The Department became an advocate at all levels of government for fair AIDS policies and was a leading member of the AIDS Action Council, the New York City HIV Health and Human Services Planning Council, and other groups of AIDS organizations.
Conclusion

At the time of this writing (2009), GMHC still provides many of the services for which it was created; but as AIDS has changed, so have its programs. The organization was created at a time when no one knew what AIDS was or how it was spread and it responded to the needs of its clients as they arose. In the beginning, GMHC provided hands-on, intensive care for PWAs in hospitals and their homes, disseminated timely and available information about AIDS to the affected populations, and provided legal advice. GMHC still provides these services, but now focuses on helping PWAs and HIV positive people to live healthy and productive lives; advocating government for fair policies and scientifically sound public health programs; and solving the legal, financial, and many other issues facing its clients.
GMHC maintains a timeline of important events in its history and the AIDS movement on its website www.gmhc.org.

scopecontent.p: The records of the Gay Men's Health Crisis (GMHC) document the three aspects of the organization's activities and contain brochures, correspondence, memoranda, minutes, pamphlets, photographs, posters, questionnaires, reports, sound recordings, surveys, video recordings, and other material. The bulk of the collection consists of correspondence, memoranda, and reports regarding GMHC's safe sex education programs and client services. The collection is arranged by the departments of the organization, beginning with the Executive Director and continuing alphabetically from the Board of Directors through Women's Education Services. The largest series is the Education Department which contains material on GMHC's groundbreaking safe sex and AIDS prevention programs, dissemination of AIDS information, and training programs for health care workers. The Client Services records contain minutes of Buddy Teams, Crisis Intervention Workers, and Crisis Management Partners meetings. These minutes contain detailed information on how the volunteers assisted PWAs, the rapid spread of AIDS in the early days of the epidemic, and the physical and emotional toll these had on the PWAs and the volunteers. More information about each department can be found in the series notes.

The records reflect the explosive growth of GMHC and often contain overlapping or similar material within and across departments. During the first ten years of its existence, the organization adapted to the needs of its clients by expanding and creating departments and creating new programs and positions. The records reflect this growth and the subsequent reorganizations of GMHC. As a result of this, some series may contain material similar to another series or one unit may contain material relating to another unit. Such incidents are described at the series and subseries levels.

bioghist.p: The Board of Directors at GMHC oversees all actions of the organization. The members of the first board were Paul Popham (also the first President of GMHC), Harry Diaz, Nathan Fain, Brad Frandsen, Joe Hernandez, Larry Kramer, Lawrence Mass, Larry McDevitt, and Joe Paschek. The first board meetings were held at members' apartments and covered all aspects of the organization, from the first fundraising events, the newsletter, and information and booths at Gay Pride Day. At the time, the board members were also employees and volunteers of GMHC and usually the only staff members of what eventually became the departments of the organization.

scopecontent.p: This series contains minutes of board meetings, packets created to prepare executive directors for board meetings, correspondence with board members, and material from committees of the board.

The minutes of the meetings of the Board of Directors begin in April 1982 with the first meetings of GMHC and continue through 1992. The minutes for the first few years reflect the organization's exponential growth from a handful of men meeting in an apartment to thousands of employees and volunteers working in a 12-story building. They contain information on the development of all aspects of GMHC, including its client services, educational mission, fundraising initiatives, and increasing public awareness about HIV/AIDS.

did.unittitle: I. B. Committees of the Board

scopecontent.p: The Board of Directors created a number of committees to conduct business in specific areas. The bulk of material in this subseries comes from the Executive Committee and the Nominating Committee. The Executive Committee oversaw GMHC's budget, nominated members of the other committees, and reviewed the work of committees and departments at GMHC. The Nominating Committee oversaw elections to the Board of Directors.

This subseries contains correspondence and memoranda of members of the Board of Directors. Topics include acknowledgment of donations, requests for meetings with members of the medical and scientific communities, offers to volunteer time, knowledge, expertise, and other services, and internal policies. Further correspondence may be found in Series II. Executive Director and in the records of the specific departments.

This subseries contains reports compiled by the departments of GMHC and sent to the Executive Director in preparation for meetings with the Board of Directors. The files also contain agenda for the meetings, clippings, brochures and newsletters from other AIDS organizations, and budget information. Further material for each Executive Director can be found in Series II. Executive Director.
This subseries contains biographies of some members of the board, material from board retreats, and self-audits completed by board members.

bioghist.p: The Executive Director oversees the work of the various departments of GMHC and reports on these to the Board of Directors. Mel Rosen was the first Executive Director of GMHC, elected in August 1982 and serving until July of 1983 when he became the Director of the AIDS Institute. Rodger McFarlane returned to GMHC that month and served as Executive Director until June 1985. Richard Dunne (1985-1989), Jeffrey Braff (1989-1990), Timothy J. Sweeney (1990-1993), and Jeff Richardson (1993-1994) served in this position and are represented in this series.

In the beginning of GMHC's history, the Executive Director was directly involved in all operations of the organization. McFarlane was responsible for moving the organization from its first office (a series of rooms in a building owned by Mel Cheren on West 22nd Street) to a larger office on West 18th Street and for formalizing some of GMHC's social programs, the Crisis Intervention Services and the Buddy Program. Dunne was the last Executive Director to have the same level of involvement with the development of the organization before it grew too large for any one person to have such a relationship.

scopecontent.p: This series contains correspondence, memoranda, minutes, reports, and other material created by and sent to the Executive Director.

bioghist.p: Richard Dunne became the Executive Director in 1985 after Rodger McFarlane left GMHC. Dunne had been involved in the organization since January 1983 when he volunteered as a Buddy. He had three clients in eight months and while he enjoyed this work, he quickly became overwhelmed by the emotional investment required from him. Dunne asked for a change and became a Buddy Team Leader in August of 1983. He enjoyed this work and remained in this position until June 1985 when he became Executive Director.

Between 1985 and 1989, Dunne oversaw huge growth in GMHC. During his four years as Executive Director, the paid staff grew from 17 to 125, the volunteer staff from 500 to 1800, and the budget from $800,000 to $12 million. He brought GMHC into the mainstream and into every conversation about HIV/AIDS. Under his direction, GMHC began to provide information on experimental drugs and therapies, started recreational programs for PWAs, and a program to help children with AIDS.
Dunne stepped down from his position in September 1989. He died on December 29, 1990 of an AIDS-related illness.

scopecontent.p: This subseries contains correspondence, memoranda, minutes, and other material created and used by Richard Dunne during his tenure as Executive Director of GMHC and material created by Mel Rosen and Rodger McFarlane, who held the position before Dunne. A great deal of the material consists of copies of articles on issues relevant to the early years of the AIDS epidemic, some with notes made by Dunne. The GMHC History folder contains correspondence and notes from 1982, including Rodger McFarlane's letter of resignation from the board, a letter from Larry Kramer to Ed Koch inviting him to the Circus and asking him to name the week of April 24, 1983 AID FOR AIDS WEEK. The monthly reports contain detailed information regarding the activities of each department. Included are statistics for Hotline calls, tabling events, and client demographics; lists of media reports regarding GMHC; developments across the organization; and the status of current projects and plans for future ones. Also of interest are the files on the AIDS Advisory Council of the AIDS Institute and the bathhouses in New York City.

bioghist.p: Jeffrey Braff served as Executive Director for less than a year in 1989-1990.

scopecontent.p: This subseries contains correspondence, memoranda, and other documents related to Jeffrey Braff's tenure as Executive Director. Of interest are the files on the appointment of Woodrow Myers as Health Commissioner of New York City and Braff's and GMHC's involvement.

bioghist.p: Timothy J. Sweeney was Executive Director of GMHC from 1990 to 1993. He started the Public Policy Department in 1986 and served as the Deputy Executive Director until 1990. While serving as Executive Director, Sweeney helped write and enact the Ryan White Comprehensive AIDS Resources Emergency (CARE) Act which provided funding for cities and states hardest hit by the AIDS epidemic to provide services with people with HIV and AIDS. He was one of the principle engineers of New York's confidentiality law, helped establish the AIDS Action Council and cofounded the New York AIDS Coalition and the Coalition for AIDS Funding.

scopecontent.p: This subseries contains correspondence, memoranda, notes, and other material chiefly related to Timothy J. Sweeney's time as Executive Director. Of interest is the correspondence with Larry Kramer and files on the AIDS Institute. Some material in this series relates to Sweeney's tenure in the Public Policy Department.

bioghist.p: Jeff Richardson was Executive Director of GMHC from 1993 to 1995. Richardson created the Department of Treatment Education and Advocacy in 1994 which expanded GMHC's advocacy for improved HIV/AIDS drug research and augmented delivery of treatment education to GMHC's clients. He also oversaw the creation of GMHC's Tuberculosis Education and Treatment Support Program during a severe outbreak of the disease in New York City.

scopecontent.p: This subseries contains correspondence, memoranda, minutes, reports, and other material from Jeff Richardson's tenure as Executive Director.

bioghist.p: The Client Programs department oversaw the various services provided by GMHC to help clients adapt to and live life with HIV/AIDS. The name of this department changed a number of times and included Program Operations and Program Management. The department was responsible for creating new programs, managing existing programs, and maintaining funding for both.
The department administered the following units:
Client Services Client Advocacy Education Department Legal Services Office of the Ombudsman Volunteer Office
Each of these units had a department head who reported to the Deputy Executive Director for Client Programs.

The records of Client Services, the Education Department, Legal Services, and the Office of the Ombudsman are not part of this series but are available respectively in Series IV, VII, IX and X of the collection . The records of the Client Advocacy department and the Volunteer Office were not transferred from GMHC, although small amounts of materials related to these departments may be found throughout the collection.

scopecontent.p: The series contains reports, memoranda, and correspondence from the Client Programs department. Included here are statistics and summary reports on existing programs and proposals for new programs. The series is divided into three subseries and contains the Administrative Files of the department, records of the Deaf AIDS Project, and records of the Tuberculosis Education and Treatment Support Program.

This series contains reports, memoranda, notes, and correspondence produced by the Client Programs department. Included are Monthly Program Reports which contain statistics and summaries of programs for the AIDS Institute and the Medical and Health Research Association of New York City. There are also proposals for the department's Immigrants with HIV-Related Illness Project and the Food Services Proposal, both funded by the first Ryan White CARE Act.

The Immigrants with HIV-Related Illness Project was created to provide legal services for immigrants in New York City with HIV-related illness. The project sought to obtain government benefits for immigrants and help with housing, discrimination, and personal affairs planning such as wills and medical directives. The Food Services Program was created in 1986 by the Recreation Department of Client Programs to provide meals five days a week to clients who were homeless, living in shelters, and/or were eligible for Medicare and/or Medicaid. The food program provided a social and safe atmosphere for clients, encouraging them to participate in the menu creation and the preparation of meals. The 1991 Proposal sought to expand the services by 15,600 more meals per week.

bioghist.p: The Deaf AIDS Project (DAP) began in 1987, independent of GMHC, when a group consisting of members of the deaf community, their supporters, and interpreters met to discuss the lack of AIDS education within the deaf community and homophobia within the environment of deaf services in New York City. English is a second language to many deaf Americans and the average deaf adult has a reading comprehension level between the third and eighth grade levels. Because of this, most of them did not know about AIDS. DAP looked to GMHC to provide a safe haven and to help form a permanent group to discuss these issues, but the two groups ran into a number of problems and were unable to form a permanent program until the early 1990s. In 1991, the DAP Staff Coordination Group was formed to create programs within GMHC that were focused on deaf clients. DAP established a Speakers Bureau to provide education about HIV/AIDS to deaf schools and organizations, implemented a TTY Hotline at GMHC, and produced HIV/AIDS videos and brochures for the deaf.

scopecontent.p: Included in this series are mock-ups and notes on the HIV/AIDS brochure for the deaf community. The minutes of the DAP Staff Coordination Group describe the initial problems encountered by DAP and GMHC, the need for DAP, and other issues in the deaf community.

did.unittitle: Deaf Accessibility Advisory Committee (DAAC), staff coordination group
III. C. Tuberculosis Education and Treatment Support Program

bioghist.p: The Tuberculosis Education and Treatment Support Program was developed in 1993 in response to the resurgence of tuberculosis (TB) in New York City. The program provided information about TB to clients, ongoing training about TB in social service settings and in the workplace, and sought to reduce the transmission of TB at GMHC facilities. Within the first year of the program HEPA filters were installed throughout the agency, tissues and face masks were made available on-site, TB posters and "cover your mouth" signs were posted in all reception areas, numerous on-site screenings for staff and clients were conducted, and a requirement was implemented for all new clients to provide documentation of their TB status.

scopecontent.p: This subseries contains reports, memoranda, and correspondence of the Tuberculosis Education and Treatment Support Program. Included here are monthly reports and yearly reviews of the Program and minutes from the TB Working Group. All of these documents detail the steps taken by the TB program to reduce transmission of the disease within GMHC's community.

did.unittitle: Bureau of Tuberculosis Control monthly reports, fiscal year 1995

bioghist.p: Client Services (known as Clinical Services until the mid 1980s) is the oldest department at GMHC, and developed out of the Buddy Program, which was initiated in 1982. The department managed the following programs:
Case Management Crisis Intervention Services Financial Advocacy Group Support Intake Unit Nutrition and Recreation Services
Each of these departments had a director or coordinator who reported to the head of Client Services.

Only the records of the Crisis Intervention Services and a small amount of material from the Intake Unit and the Nutrition and Recreation Services were transferred from GMHC. Some material from the other Client Services departments may be found dispersed throughout the collection.

scopecontent.p: Included are training manuals and handbooks, statistics on clients, and recreation program descriptions. There are three subseries, the Administrative Files, records of the Crisis Intervention Services, and Nutrition Assessment Forms. Audiovisual materials associate with these records can be found in Series XVI.B.1.

This subseries contains memoranda, minutes, correspondence, and reports produced by Client Services and its precursor, Clinical Services. Included are Buddy Support Program training manuals and Crisis Intervention Team handbooks which detail the roles of the Buddy and Crisis workers. Material from the Intake and Referral Department which includes manuals, statistics compiled by the Department of the numbers of clients admitted, memoranda, and client forms. Records of Recreation Services include descriptions of the program and the types of events sponsored, records of activities for 1987-1990, and client questionnaires. There are also minutes from Client Services staff meetings for 1983-1987 which reflect the growth of the department.

bioghist.p: Crisis Intervention Services administered the three crisis programs at GMHC:
Buddy Program Crisis Intervention Workers Crisis Management Partners
These services were generally the first a PWA received upon arriving at GMHC and provided emotional support and assistance with social services.

The Buddy Program was one of the first services provided by GMHC, begun in 1982 as a formal program continuing the work of people helping their friends and lovers who were affected by AIDS. Buddies were volunteers who assisted PWAs with everyday tasks such as shopping, laundry, dog walking, as well as providing companionship. Team meetings were held at members' apartments and included accounts of what they had done the previous month with their client and reports on the client's mental and physical status, living situation, and any other particulars deemed important by the team member.

The Crisis Intervention Worker (CIW) program evolved out of the Buddy Program. As more and more people became infected with AIDS and were turned away from hospitals or refused services from other agencies, Buddies started to act as intermediaries. GMHC soon divided the two areas of responsibility, leaving the Buddies to provide more emotional and practical support while the CIW handled social services issues for the client. The role of the CIW expanded over time to include peer counseling and to act as a liaison between the client, GMHC, and other agencies. The CIW generally worked with the client for a few weeks, while the Buddy would stay with the client as long as was needed.
The Crisis Management Partner program began in 1985 and combined the roles of the Buddies and the Crisis Intervention Workers (CIW).

scopecontent.p: This subseries contains the meeting minutes for the programs administered by the Crisis Intervention Services Department. The minutes reflect on an individual level the impact of the AIDS epidemic. They contain discussions of the problems encountered by volunteers seeking to help their clients; address methodology and the need for maintaining confidentiality; and consider the difficulties encountered assisting clients, and the psychological and emotional effects on the volunteers.

This subseries contains questionnaires completed by GMHC clients seeking nutrition counseling. These questionnaires include charts detailing what the client ate over the course of a day, medical tests they received, and weight gain/loss results.

bioghist.p: The Communications Department (originally known as the Public Information Department) was responsible for the dissemination of public information on AIDS; press relations with GMHC; advocacy advertisement campaigns and policy issues for internal communications regarding clients, volunteers, and staff. Members of the department strove to ensure that stories on AIDS were reported accurately and sensitively. The department was also responsible for publishing the monthly News from GMHC, the bimonthly The Volunteer, and the annual reports which were sent to clients, volunteers, and donors.

scopecontent.p: This subseries contains the Administrative Files of the Communications Department which consists of memoranda and reports for various departments within GMHC describing their programs. Communications and the Public Policy Department worked closely together and there are files within this subseries reflecting their collaboration. There are also lists of reporters and news sources with which GMHC had contact. The file entitled Media Reporting contains letters to editors of various newspapers and a paper on media coverage of AIDS before Rock Hudson's revelation that he had the disease.

bioghist.p: The Development Department was responsible for raising the majority of GMHC's funding through direct mail, foundation and governmental funding, donors, and special events. The department sought to raise most of its funds from its special events, rather than be dependant on government programs. The special events created by GMHC included circuses, dance-a-thons, the AIDS Walk, art auctions, the Morning Party, and many others.

scopecontent.p: This series is divided into three subseries: Administrative Files; Special Events; and the records of Patricia Evert who served as Assistant Director of Development and Special Events Director. Audiovisual materials associate with these records can be found in Series XVI.B.2.

This subseries contains correspondence, memoranda, reports, and minutes of the Development Department. Included are memoranda on the capital campaigns conducted by GMHC and correspondence with donors.

Later events such as the various Art Auctions and Dance-A-Thons contain memoranda and minutes from planning meetings that document the development of these events.

bioghist.p: The Education Department was responsible for providing information to the public about HIV/AIDS and treatments available for PWAs. The structure of the department changed over time, but the basic services provided were general information, outreach, prevention, and training. The department consisted of the following units:
AIDS Prevention AIDS Professional Education Program Community Health Education Services Information and Training Services Treatment Education and Advocacy
Each of these departments had a director or coordinator who reported directly to the Director of the Education Department.

scopecontent.p: The series is arranged by departmental units and two general categories: Surveys and Questionnaires and Topical Files. These last two categories contain material maintained and utilized across the department. Audiovisual materials associate with these records can be found in Series XVI.B.3.
This subseries contains the records of two of the Directors of the Education Department, Charles McKinney and Ana Oliveira, which consist of correspondence, memoranda, minutes, and reports.

bioghist.p: The AIDS Prevention division of the Education Department provided HIV/AIDS prevention information, risk reduction programs, and behavior change interventions to various communities. The programs were aimed at specific groups with the exception of the Street Outreach program which targeted the general public. Understanding Safer Sex, Keep It Up!, and Eroticizing Safer Sex were some of the workshops developed by this division. The division also distributed literature at gay bathhouses and other gay sex venues and continued the organization's outreach activities of staffing information tables around New York City.

scopecontent.p: Records from the AIDS Prevention division of the Education Department consist of correspondence, memoranda, reports, minutes, and other documents. Included in these are brochures published and distributed by the division, monthly reports on its programs, and program evaluations.

VII. C. AIDS Professional Education Program (APEP)

bioghist.p: The AIDS Professional Education Program (APEP), begun in 1986, provided free, on-site training workshops at community-based mental health agencies, alcoholism programs, community residences, and hospitals. Sessions were aimed at small groups of mental health professionals which met for four or more weekly sessions. Participants were given information about HIV/AIDS, referral resources, and useful counseling and risk behavior modification therapies. APEP trainers would tailor sessions to each organization's needs and the existing level of HIV/AIDS knowledge of its staff.

scopecontent.p: This subseries contains memoranda, reports, manuals, correspondence, and other material from the AIDS Professional Education Program (APEP). Included are manuals for APEP trainers, files detailing the background and skills of the trainers, and reports on trainings. The training reports contain correspondence between APEP and interested organizations, notes from sessions, and sign-in sheets for sessions listing attendees and their position or title.

VII. D. Community Health Education Services (CHES)

bioghist.p: The Community Health Education Services (CHES) division of the Education Department was responsible for delivering AIDS information to the public via information tables, direct mail and telephone campaigns, as well as connecting with underserved communities. CHES accomplished these goals through a series of programs and initiatives: the Community Support Network, People of Color AIDS Prevention program, the Speakers' Bureau, and the distribution of pamphlets though tabling events.

The Community Support Network (CSN) began in 1982 and maintained the distribution and collection of donation cans and literature at gay establishments, mostly bars and bathhouses. By 1988, more than 300 establishments in New York City participated in CSN.

The People of Color AIDS Prevention (POC) program conducted outreach to gay and bisexual men of minority communities, mainly Blacks and Latinos. POC adapted its literature for these communities, created focus groups and advisory panels made up of members of the communities. Programs targeted at these communities included What's in it 4 Me?, a workshop by and for gay black men and Noche de Ronda ,a safe sex play in Spanish.

The Speakers' Bureau was staffed by volunteers who gave presentations on HIV/AIDS and safe sex, their personal experiences with AIDS, homophobia and AIDS, and women and AIDS. These presentations were free and held at community centers, churches, schools, anywhere groups of people gathered. Tabling was another early program of GMHC. Volunteers distributed literature and were stationed at information tables throughout New York City in high traffic areas, especially ones with large populations of gay men. The service expanded to tables scheduled for street fairs, conferences, and health fairs.

scopecontent.p: This subseries contains memoranda, reports, correspondence, and other material related to the Community Health Education Services division of the Education Department. The subseries is divided into eight sub-subseries: the Administrative Files of the department, the files of the Assistant Coordinator, the Assistant Director, and the Coordinator, the Community Support Network (CSN), the People of Color AIDS Prevention program, the Speakers' Bureau, and the Tabling initiative. Included here are information sheets on CSN establishments; statistical reports listing numbers and locations of literature and condoms distributed; assessments of outreach tables; plans for expansions of the division; the log of the Volunteer Manager which contains daily entries describing volunteer interviews, work done by volunteers, and other events of the day; memoranda on planned bar interventions and zaps; correspondence with organizations requesting Speakers' Bureau presentations; and reports on these events.

VII. E. Information and Training Services

bioghist.p: The Information and Training Services division of the Education Department was responsible for the Hotline telephone service; the A-Team which provided information for walk-ins to GMHC and follow-up for Hotline callers; overseeing the AIDS Professional Education Program (APEP); training new staff and volunteers; and providing continuing education programs to keep the entire Department up to date about AIDS.

scopecontent.p: This subseries contains correspondence, memoranda, minutes, reports and other material from the Information and Training Services division of the Education Department. The subseries is divided into the files of the Assistant Director and the Training Coordinator. Included here are memoranda and reports on program development, reports on in-service trainings for Education Department staff and volunteers, requests for training sessions for AIDS service providers other than GMHC including profiles of the organization requesting training, and questionnaires completed by participants in the training programs.

bioghist.p: The purpose of The Study was to identify levels of knowledge, attitudes, and behavioral risks for HIV/AIDS among gay and bisexual men, to create effective AIDS prevention and risk behavior modification programs, to evaluate the effectiveness of current programs, and to promote a sense of control in the participants.

scopecontent.p: The files on The Study contain forms filled out by survey participants, progress reports, and a summary of the findings.

VII. H. Treatment, Education and Advocacy

bioghist.p: The Treatment Education and Advocacy division of the Education Department was created in 1993 to provide up-to-date information on current and experimental HIV/AIDS therapies to the general public. The material that was transferred from this department consists of historical files that pre-date the establishment of this unit.

scopecontent.p: The bulk of this material is correspondence with public health, university, government, and research organizations regarding Treatment Issues, TEA's advocacy work, the participation of employees of the division in conferences and workshops on HIV/AIDS, and other topics.

did.unittitle: New York City Department of Health

bioghist.p: The Evaluation Research Department was officially established in 1993 with the consolidation of program evaluation and research service staff into one unit. Members of the department conducted quality assurance audits on GMHC programs; assisted other departments in their work, such as the effective development of ad campaigns and brochures; and conducted studies with other agencies and institutions. These collaborations included the Linkage Project, where GMHC and the Jewish Board of Family and Child Services worked to assign mental health professionals to PWAs; and in the development of the Deaf AIDS Project, where GMHC consulted with staff from the New York Society for the Deaf. In conjunction with the Research Ethics Committee (formally the Institutional Review Board until 1996), the department evaluated internal and external project proposals from researchers interested in conducting studies at GMHC.

scopecontent.p: This series contains memoranda, project proposals, questionnaires, surveys, interview transcripts, reports, and grant applications. The series is divided into three subseries: Administrative Files, Research Materials, and Topical Files. Audiovisual materials associate with these records can be found in Series XVI.B.4.

This subseries contains the Administrative Files of the Evaluation Research Department, maintained by the directors and assistant directors of the department, and proposals submitted to the Research Ethics Committee. Included in this subseries are audits of GMHC programs, development and feedback on research studies and client programs such as the Deaf AIDS Project (DAP), Gay Men of African Descent (GMAD), House of Latex (HOL) and Substance Use Counseling and Education (SUCE). Also included are applications for state and city funding that provide an overview of the department's projects and activities.

Series X. Office of the Ombudsman

bioghist.p: The Office of the Ombudsman was created in 1984 as part of Client Services and became its own department in 1986. The Ombudsman sought to provide advocacy services for PWAs who did not receive satisfactory services through the healthcare and social services systems. The Ombudsman also investigated complaints from within and outside GMHC.

scopecontent.p: This series contains correspondence, memoranda, minutes, reports, and other material from the Office of the Ombudsman at GMHC. The series contains three subseries, Administrative Files, Case Files, and Resource Information Files.

This subseries contains the Administrative Files of the directors of the Office of the Ombudsman and consists of correspondence, memoranda, reports, and other material regarding the many areas in which PWAs were discriminated against. Included are reports on the funeral industry's reaction to the AIDS crisis, handbooks and briefings on patients' rights, data on other organizations' hotlines, and information on prisoners' rights. The materials in this series were created and utilized by the staff of the Office of the Ombudsman.

bioghist.p: The Public Policy Department lobbied government at all levels for fair HIV/AIDS policies; published policy statements on these issues; led HIV/AIDS coalitions; and provided information on the positions of elected officials on these issues.

scopecontent.p: The series is divided into five subseries: Administrative Files, the Alcohol and Other Drugs Workgroup, the Committee for AIDS Funding, Organizations Files, and Topical Files.

The files of the Public Policy Department consist of correspondence and reports on GMHC's response to the Centers for Disease Control's definitions of AIDS and their efforts to have more groups included in the definition. There are correspondence, minutes, and reports from the New York City HIV Health and Human Services Planning Council which, among other things, prioritized allocation of funds from the Ryan White CARE Act and monitored health care services for PWAs in New York City. Also included are files on legislation regarding HIV/AIDS and GMHC's opinion on the bills and files on the development of GMHC's policy on HIV testing, Social Security benefits for PWAs, and other issues.

XII. B. Alcohol and Other Drugs Workgroup

bioghist.p: The Alcohol and Other Drugs Workgroup was part of the New York City HIV Health and Human Services Planning Council. Richard Elovich was the chairperson of the Workgroup and the director of GMHC's Substance Use Counseling and Education program. The group worked on developing programs for HIV-infected substance abusers and expanding Ryan White CARE Act funding for these types of programs.

scopecontent.p: This subseries contains correspondence, memoranda, minutes, and reports from the Alcohol and Other Drugs Workgroup. Included here is correspondence with state and federal officials regarding expansion of funding and development of program drug users with HIV/AIDS.

bioghist.p: The Committee for AIDS Funding was a coalition of members of various AIDS organizations in New York City which lobbied the New York City government for increased funding of AIDS programs and fair HIV/AIDS policies. Timothy J. Sweeney was the chairperson.

scopecontent.p: Included here are agenda and minutes from Committee meetings, correspondence with various members of the Committee and city officials, and material on the Citywide Speak Out on AIDS! at which Committee members gave testimony on underfunded programs, unfair policies towards PWAs, and other issues.

Series XIII. Staff Groups and Events

scopecontent.p: This series contains correspondence, memoranda, minutes, and other material from various Staff Groups and Events at GMHC. Included are agenda, memoranda, and minutes related to meetings attended by and memoranda sent to the entire staff; minutes from meetings of the Assistant Directors Group; flyers from miscellaneous staff groups at GMHC announcing classes, support groups, events, and special offers for staff members; memoranda and minutes of meetings of the Staff Caucus, created in 1989 to improve communication between the staff and management of GMHC; and material from the Union Organizing Committee.

bioghist.p: The Assistant Directors Group consisted of assistant directors from all departments of GMHC who met to discuss staff issues, updates for departments, and other topics. All assistant directors were welcome to attend the meetings but not all did.
The Staff Caucus was created in 1989 to improve communication between the staff and management of GMHC. All staff members were welcome to join and representatives were elected from each department.

The Union Organizing Committee developed in 1993 from the Staff Caucus and attempted to organize under Local 1199 United Healthcare Workers. The Committee sought to strengthen the job security, bargaining strength, and voice of the staff. Issues of racism, job security, and the attitude of the management towards the Staff Caucus led to this unionization attempt. The unionization vote was held on February 4, 1994, resulted in a split decision, and the staff did join Local 1199.

did.unittitle: Series XIV. Substance Use Counseling and Education Program

bioghist.p: The Substance Use Counseling and Education (SUCE) program was created in 1993 and provided group counseling and education sessions for gay and bisexual men who felt that drugs and/or alcohol were affecting the decisions they made about sex. SUCE also produced educational materials regarding drug and alcohol use and safe sex.

scopecontent.p: This series contains correspondence, memoranda, minutes, questionnaires, reports, and other material from the Substance Use Counseling and Education program at GMHC. The series is divided into two subseries: Administrative Files and Group Files. Audiovisual materials associate with these records can be found in Series XVI.B.5.

Included here are minutes and reports from the HIV Planning Council's Alcohol and Other Drugs Workgroup which developed SUCE, manuals for SUCE staff, questionnaires completed by SUCE participants, and notes on group sessions.

bioghist.p: The Women's Education Services (WES) division of GMHC was created in 1996 and was an expansion of existing programs for women at GMHC. WES grew from the Lesbian AIDS Project, which became a part of WES but remained a distinct program. WES promoted existing GMHC programs for women, adapted programs aimed at heterosexual couples to the needs of lesbian, bisexual, and transgendered women, developed brochures and safe sex kits for women, and established support groups focusing on parenting and relationships.

scopecontent.p: This series contains correspondence, memoranda, and other material from the Women's Education Services division of GMHC and is divided into two sections: Administrative Files and the Lesbian AIDS Project (LAP). LAP was created to conduct outreach to HIV positive lesbians, make them feel welcome at GMHC, and provide education and other services. Included in the Administrative Files are files on the creation of brochures for WES, the development of Women's Open Houses held at GMHC, and workshops for women. The LAP section contains manuals for workshops and memoranda on LAP Notes, the program's quarterly national newsletter.

did.unittitle: Evaluation Research reviews of Women's Programs

bioghist.p: The Lesbian AIDS Project (LAP) was created in 1994 as part of the Education Department and became part of the Women's Education Services division in 1996. The purpose of LAP was to connect with HIV positive lesbians, make them welcome at GMHC, and provide education and other services.

The Audiovisual Department was created to raise public awareness; serve as a means of communicating the medical, social, and psychological ramifications of the HIV/AIDS epidemic; and to support prevention and training programs. In addition to producing its own programming, the department assisted other GMHC departments by documenting training and creating promotional and outreach videos. The department, created in 1987, was staffed by an audiovisual specialist, Jean Carlomusto, and an assistant coordinator, Gregg Bordowitz. It was originally under the auspices of the Publications Department but then became part of the Education Department. In addition to Carlomusto and Bordowitz, other videographers represented in the collection are Marina Alvarez, Chas B. Brack, Sarah Cawley, Ronald Dodd, Andres J. Figueroa, Alexandra Juhasz, Juanita Mohammed, Ray Navarro, Steven Okazaki, Catherine Saalfield, Kristen Thomas, and Paul Zakrzewskiand .

scopecontent.p: This series consists of 989 video recordings including both original footage and masters of completed works. GMHC produced broadcasted programs for television, oral histories, and miscellaneous programs to disseminate information about HIV/AIDS. The bulk of the material consists of original and unedited footage used for the Living with AIDS television show. Also represented are productions geared to specific cultural groups, young adults, interviews with PWAs, caretakers and other service providers, and films demonstrating safer sex practices.

This series includes productions created by the Audiovisual Department to be aired regularly on public access television. The department ran three different series: AIDS Network, Outreach, and Living with AIDS. These broadcast productions represent the bulk of the department's efforts; this series contains the majority of raw footage found this collection, most notably the original, unedited interviews.

AIDS Network was a thirty-minute program that aired on public access television and was a precursor to the Living with AIDS show. Each show was introduced by Lori Behrman and included live interviews with caretakers, service providers and PWAs. All videos in this sub-series are mastered productions of aired episodes of AIDS Network.

Living with AIDS was a thirty-minute program that aired regularly on public access television and sought to provide quality programming to people with AIDS. The first episode aired in 1987 and the series ran until 1997. Initially the show was filmed as either a short documentary or as a live show with a panel of guests discussing a single topic, but overtime it evolved into more of a magazine-based format, each show being made up of 8-10 minute segments. The shows were repackaged and reaired in a changing combination of segments. These segments were topical in nature, broad in scope and content, covering a variety of topics such as healthcare and treatment; activism; risk reduction strategies; raising families; and maintaining relationships. Recurring segments were Medical Updates, which provided users with up to the minute treatment information and updates on medical issues in other countries, such as Germany and Japan; and Video Portraits, which were short portrayals of individuals who were infected or affected by AIDS.

This subseries contains the documentary style shows, live shows and segments of Living with AIDS, arranged in one general run alphabetically. It also includes focus group sessions on audio tapes. The focus groups were part of a study to ascertain how people received information about AIDS and their opinions on the Living with AIDS show. Also included are videos that were produced by unrelated videographers and screened during GMHC programs, such as John Greyson's The Pink Pimpernel and The World is Sick".

This subseries contains audiovisual material produced for the Education Department and consists of video and audio tapes created to educate clients about HIV/AIDS, treatment options, and other issues facing PWAs. This subseries is divided into six sections, each containing programs designed for specific populations.

Beyond 2000 (B2K) was a sexual health program and survey that recruited 2000 gay men, regardless of HIV status, in volunteer efforts to help uninfected gay men stay free of HIV as the 21st century approached. Gay Men of African Descent (GMAD) includes interviews with African American men with substance abuse issues. House of Latex videos contain footage of events thrown by the ballroom and vogueing community as well as interviews with community members. Safer sex productions, which are explicit in content, were produced to demonstrate that sensuality need not be sacrificed for safety. Also represented are productions geared specifically to women including client and staff interviews and footage from the Multicultural HIV Prevention for Women Conference. Young adults are also represented in this subseries. Highlights are Youth at Risk, a production that contains interviews with youth activists and footage from the Conference of Peer Educators (COPE), and It is What it Is, a film geared towards teenagers that addressed sexuality, homophobia, and safer sex.

bioghist.p: Richard Dunne created the oral history program at GMHC in the late 1980s in order to document the history of the organization and its role in the AIDS crisis. Dunne was an avid historian who recognized the importance of the historical record for future understanding of events. He realized the importance of GMHC and wanted to ensure that its history was not lost. He encouraged surviving founders, early members, and others to record their roles and memories of GMHC through this program.

scopecontent.p: This subseries contains miscellaneous productions of the Audiovisual Department that do not fit into any of the above series or were collaborations between GMHC and other organizations,. Included are interviews with participants in Project Connect, New York City's first mental health and substance abuse program for gay men and lesbians sponsored by the Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual & Transgender Community Center, and the Fortune Society, a program for currently and formerly incarcerated individuals. There are interviews with serodiscordant couples (couples in which one partner is HIV positive and the other is HIV negative) that were conducted for I Love Her Just the Same, I Love Him Just the Same. Also included are memorial services of notable GMHC staff members and other AIDS activists and a tribute video to volunteer Judy Peabody and GMHC's 10th Anniversary video.
